comments.author: mary
comments.content: Wow, loved this recipe.  I had to make a few changes, I used thin fresh asparagus and cremini mushrooms, the saffron was so pleasing and made the dish.  Since I was making a smaller portion I used only 1 cup of the arborio rice and parmesan for the cheese.  I topped it off with a few shrimp I had left over from dinner yesterday and a fresh chopped tomato with a tiny squeeze of lemon juice.  Thanks for the inspiration!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: So awesome that I just posted it today and you've already made it! That makes my day.

comments.author: Lawrence
comments.content:
I first tried Risotto after seeing it feature so much on the food programmes.  It never sounded too tasty but then I tried it and have been hooked ever since.
Not only do I like the taste and the fact that there are so many different ways to make it but the making is so therapeutic.  
I take it slowly and my mind reflects on a million things.
So another one to try.  The cream cheese sounds interesting 
I have saffron but (embarrassed to admit) have never really noticed the taste of it.  Maybe I don't add enough because it is so expensive.

comments.author: The Mistress of Spices
comments.content: Lovely idea with the watercress puree! And I just happen to have xanthan gum...will have to make some to serve alongside this luscious risotto!

comments.author: John
comments.content:
I liked this idea so much I made it two days in a row. The first time I couldn't find watercress, and didn't have  triple-cream cheese. So I skipped the puree, and used some grated Mahon cheese instead. Wonderful! BTW, if you have a nice tall microwave-safe rice-and-pasta cooker, this can all be done in the microwave. Roughly 4-5 minutes per cup of liquid in my somewhat old microwave. I made the onions and rice in a skillet, added the wine, then added the first cup of stock, and once it was warm, transferred it to the microwave pasta cooker. I could then deal with other aspects of dinner with just a quick stir-and-pour every 5 min. 

(I also blanched the peas and asparagus in the microwave. For pinkie-thickness asparagus, about 2.5 min works for me.)

The second day I had the watercress (but no xanthan gum. I used a little olive oil --  mostly to get it to stop sticking to the sides of my mini-chopper -- and it worked fine). Made for a really nice flavor combination. The balance of the saffron and the cheese seemed exactly right. Another "Michael recipe" to go on the short rotation. :)
